<h1>Lab 1 - Part 1: <!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span><span

"1" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]-->Experiments
for Week 1<!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span>
TC "Experiments for the 1st Week" \f C \l "1" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3>Lab 1, Part 1 covers the following Chapters in the Wilder
text: 1, 2.1-1.5, 3 up to 3.3.2, 6.1-3, in the Stevens text: 1, 2, 3</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>Objectives</b><!--[if supportFields]><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span></b> TC "<b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>1.1	Objective</b>" \f C \l
"2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span></b><![endif]--><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l6 level1 lfo8;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Getting acquainted with the Unix/Linux/Solaris and
Xwindows environment</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l6 level1 lfo8;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Preview of some TCP/IP diagnostic tools</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l6 level1 lfo8;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Capturing link/IP/TCP layer header</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l6 level1 lfo8;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>The usage of port numbers and IP protocol field</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Times;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:
EN-US;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA'><br clear=all style='page-break-before:always'>
</span></b>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Basic Unix/Linux/Solaris Commands<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span> TC "1.2	Basic Unix
Commands" \f C \l "2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The basic Unix commands are
summarized below; see the manual pages for various options.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>man</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>word<span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span></i>:<span style='mso-tab-count:
1'>            </span>getting online help</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>e.g., <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>man ls</b> displays the manual explanation of <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>ls</b>.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>info</b> <i>word<span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span></i>:<span style='mso-tab-count:
1'>            </span>getting online help. Type <b>info</b> <i>info</i> to get
help on how to use <b>info</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>passwd</b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>:<span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>setting (changing) your password</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>pwd<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>      </span><span style='mso-tab-count:
1'>            </span></b>:<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>displays
the current working directory</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>ls<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>         </span><span style='mso-tab-count:
1'>            </span></b>:<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>lists
the contents of a directory</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>more </b><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>file_name</i><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span></b>:<span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To scroll through a file.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To
list the next page, press the space bar.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To
go backwards, press b.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To
quit from <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>more</b>, press q.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>mv</b> <span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>old_file_name new_file_name</i><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>          </span>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> 
</span>renaming a file.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>file_name directory_name</i><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>          </span>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> 
</span>move a file to a directory.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>old_directory_name new_directory_name</i><span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">   </span><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>:<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>move an entire directory.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>rm</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>file_name</i><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>:<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>deletes(removes)
a file.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>mkdir</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>directory_name</i><span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>        </span>:<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>creates a directory.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>rmdir</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>directory_name</i><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>          </span>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> 
</span>removes a directory.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>cd</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>directory_name</i><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>          </span>: <span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>changes
a current working directory to be <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>directory_name</i>.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>If
<i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>directory_name</i> is omitted, the shell
is moved to your home directory.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>cp</b> <span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>file_name new_file_name</i><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>          </span>:<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>copying
a file.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>file_name directory_name</i><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>          </span>:<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>copying
a file into <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>directory_name</i>.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>chmod </b><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>who op-code permission
file_or_directory_name</i> :<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>change
the file access permissions.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>who</i><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>     </span><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>:<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>u</b> user</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>:<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>g</b> group</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>:<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>o</b> other users</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>:<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>a</b> all (user, group, and other)</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>op-code<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>     </span></i>:<span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>+ add permission</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>-
remove permission</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>permission</i><span style='mso-tab-count:
1'>      </span>:<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>r</b> read</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>w</b> write</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>x</b> execute </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>ps</b> <span style='mso-tab-count:1'>       </span><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> 
</span>the process status report</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>kill</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>PID</i> <span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> 
</span>terminates the job corresponding to <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>PID</i>.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>Ctrl-c<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>   </span><span style='mso-tab-count:
1'>            </span></b>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>Pressing
the keyboard sequence <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Ctrl-c</b>
terminates the job before it is finished.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Terminal Window</h2>

<p class=MsoNormal>To bring up a terminal window on a Linux PC, left click your
mouse on the <b>Terminal Emulation</b> button on the <b>Taskbar</b>.</p>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.3<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Text Editors<!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:
field-begin'></span> TC "1.3	Text Editors" \f C \l "2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The following text editors are
available on the PC’s under Linux. You should consult the <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>man</i> pages for more details.</p>

<h3><![if !supportLists]>1.3.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span><![endif]>vi editor<!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span>
TC "1.3.1	vi editor" \f C \l "3" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>The<b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'> vi</b> editor is one of the most popular
UNIX text editors. <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>vi</b> is considered
to be the default text editor of the UNIX system.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To
start <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>vi</b>, enter <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>vi</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>file_name</i><span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>at the command line. If no such file exists
yet, it will be created. Initially, <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>vi</b>
enters command mode and awaits instructions.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>vi</b> can be in one of the two modes, <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>command mode</i><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">  </span>and <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>text entry mode</i>.
Command mode allows you to use a number of commands to modify text. Text is
inserted and modified within text entry mode.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To
delete a single character, place the cursor over the character and press the <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>x</b> key. To delete a word, type<b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'> dw</b>, after placing the cursor at the
start of the word. A line can be deleted with <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>dd</b>, when the cursor is anywhere on the line that you want to
delete.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>From
command mode, you may enter text entry mode again using one of the keys that we
explained before. Or, if you want to save the file and quit <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>vi</b>, press <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>Esc </b>(even is you are in command mode, it doesn’t hurt), and type <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>:wq</b>. To quit<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'> vi</b> without saving changes to the file, use the command <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>:q!</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<h3><![if !supportLists]>1.3.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span><![endif]>Text Editor<!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:
field-begin'></span> TC "1.3.2	Text Editor from Workspace Menu" \f
C \l "3" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:
field-end'></span><![endif]--></h3>

<p class=MsoBodyTextIndent>Linux provides an interactive ASCII text editor that
is intuitive and is easy to use. It is especially convenient for the DOS
editor-oriented user. You can invoke the text editor by typing in the terminal
window:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>kedit</b> </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>or from the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>K Menu</b> (which can be invoked by clicking the left mouse-button on
the big <b>K</b> icon on the <b>Taskbar</b>), select the -> <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Applications </b>menu and select -> <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Text Editor</b>.</p>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.4<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Unix Tools<!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:
field-begin'></span> TC "1.4	Unix Tools" \f C \l "2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<h3><![if !supportLists]>1.4.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span><![endif]>Floppy Disk<!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:
field-begin'></span> TC "1.4.3	Floppy Disk" \f C \l "3" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The following tools can be used
in the Unix environment for copying, printing and saving<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>to a floppy.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><u>1. Mounting a Floppy</u>:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>In order to use floppy disks,
insert an MS-DOS formatted floppy disk into the floppy disk drive. Then mount
the floppy using the commands:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes"> </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:.5in'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>mount </b><i><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'><span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> </span>/mnt/floppy</span></i><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>This command will mount a floppy
disk under the directory: <i><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>/mnt</span></i>.
Then use /mnt/<i><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>floppy</span></i> to
refer to your floppy, e.g.: <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ls </b><i><span
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>/mnt/floppy</span></i><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To
manipulate the files in the floppy disk, use the same Unix commands as usual
(e.g. to copy a file into the floppy disk, </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>cp</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>file_name</i>
<span style='mso-tab-count:1'> </span><i><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>/mnt/floppy</span></i></p>

<p class=HTMLBody><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Times'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=HTMLBody style='margin-left:.5in'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>When you are done, you
<u>need</u> to <u>un mount</u> the floppy using the following command:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=HTMLBody style='margin-left:1.0in'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=HTMLBody style='margin-left:1.0in'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>umount<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span></span></b><i><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>/mnt/floppy</span></i><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=HTMLBody style='margin-left:1.0in'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=HTMLBody><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=HTMLBody style='margin-left:.5in'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>This will un mount the
floppy. If you eject before un mounting you will crash the machine!<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=HTMLBody><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Times New Roman"'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=HTMLBody style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in'><u><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>2.
Using <b>mtools</b><o:p></o:p></span></u></p>

<p class=HTMLBody><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Times New Roman"'>You can also use MS-Dos formatted floppies
directly under Linux without having to mount the floppy. <b>mtools</b> consists
of a public domain collection of<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>tools
that allow Unix based systems to manipulate MS-Dos files (read, write, move,
copy, etc) without having to mount and unmount the filesystem.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=HTMLBody><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Times New Roman"'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=HTMLBody><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Times New Roman"'>The following are some commonly used <b>mtools</b>
commands:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=HTMLBody><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Times New Roman"'>mdir</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>: directory list<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=HTMLBody><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Times New Roman"'>mcd</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>: change directory<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=HTMLBody><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Times New Roman"'>mcopy</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>: copy file<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=HTMLBody><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Times New Roman"'>mde</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>l: delete file<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=HTMLBody><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Times New Roman"'>mrd</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>: remove directory<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=HTMLBody><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Times New Roman"'>mmove</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>: move file or
directory<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=HTMLBody><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Times New Roman"'>mren</span></b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>: rename file or
directory<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h3><![if !supportLists]>1.4.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span><![endif]>System Failures</h3>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in'>When the systems crash you can
always use the command:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>reboot<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>to get started again.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><u><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Get acquainted with Unix

<h2 style='margin-right:0in'><![if !supportLists]>1.5<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Port Numbers<!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:
field-begin'></span> TC "1.5	Exercises on Port Number" \f C \l
"2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Many
TCP/IP communication services (telnet, ftp, etc.) are handled by a daemon
called <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>inetd</b>. Instead of running
many network-related daemons, the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>inetd</b>
daemon starts the necessary server processes when requests arrive. When a
client requests a certain service from a remote server, the client contacts the
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>inetd</b> daemon through the server’s
well-known port number for the service. Then the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>inetd</b> starts the corresponding server process. The well-known port
numbers are listed in the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>/etc/services</b>
file.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>The
server can handle multiple clients at the same time through the same well-known
port number of a service. The client usually uses an ephemeral port number.
Thus, the uniqueness of a communication session between two hosts is preserved
by means of the port number and IP address pair of the server and client hosts.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>We
start with a simple one segment network for which all four PCs are in one
Ethernet segment. The table below lists the IP addresses that are initially
assigned to the PC network interfaces (note: <b>ifconfig</b> was used to setup
the host IP addresses). Connect all 4 PCs via Ethernet cables to a single <i>Ethernet
hub</i> to create a single segment network.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<div align=center>

<table border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style='border-collapse:collapse;
 border:none;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .75pt;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
 <tr>
  <td width=163 valign=top style='width:1.7in;border:solid windowtext .75pt;
  padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>130.91.66.100</p>
  </td>
  <td width=163 valign=top style='width:1.7in;border:solid windowtext .75pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .75pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>apple.uci.edu</p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 3</u></b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>       </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Execute a TCP utility, <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>telnet</b> for example (<b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>telnet</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>other_ machine</i>), while <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump
</b>is running (always use a separate window in which to run<b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'> tcpdump</b> - to exit from <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump</b> use Ctrl C) to capture the
packets between <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>your_machine</i> and the <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>other_machine</i>. (Note that <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>your_machine</i> refers to a machine that
you are currently active on (i.e., have an open window in which you are
typing), <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>other_machine</i> refers to one
of the other machines in the cluster.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump
-n host</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>your_machine</i> <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>and</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>other_machin</i>e<span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>          </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>(Note: Since we don’t run a
domain name server, and don’t want to change the<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'> /etc/hosts</b> file for every experiment we run, always use the <b>IP
address</b> (for e.g. 130.91.66.100) and not the <b>PC name </b>(e.g.,
apple.uci.edu). All references in this text to, <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>host</i>, <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>your_machine</i>, <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>other_machine</i>, etc. assume IP
addresses.) Please recall that you<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'> </b>need
to open two windows: one for <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump</b>
and one for the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>telnet</b> session.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Note: to save the t<b>cpdump</b>
output to a file outpu.txt on your computer you can use the following command: </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>tcpdump –w</b> <i>/tmp/output.txt</i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>To read and parse the output file
use the following options with<b> tcpdump:<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b>tcpdump –r </b><i>/tmp/outfile.txt</i>:
read the output file<b><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.5in'><b>tcpdump
–r </b><i>/tmp/output.txt</i><b> –v host</b> <i>your_machine</i> <b>and</b> <i>other_machine</i>:
read and parse the output file in verbose mode</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.5in'>You
can also just redirect the output from screen to a file: <b>tcpdump –ex</b>
> output.txt</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.5in'>Read
output.txt using any text editor.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.7<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Network Load and MTU<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span> TC "2.3	Network Load and
MTU" \f C \l "2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Getting
accurate network statistics (load) needs sophisticated and expensive network
analysis equipment. As an alternative, network load can be estimated by
examining the collision rate on each machine’s network interface. Depending on
the criteria for the network performance, you can determine when your network
should be subnetted (or divided), based upon the collision rates for the
machines on your network.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>The
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>netstat</b> command can be used to see
the statistics of the network interface card. The same command is also used for
examining the routing table of the machine. The collision rate of a machine is
obtained by taking the ratio of the number of collisions to the number of
output packets. The average collision rate is the average of the statistics for
all the hosts on the network.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 1</u></b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>       </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Using <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>netstat -in</b> command, check the statistics on the network for your
Ethernet interface. If you don’t see any significant amount of output packets,
the machine was probably restarted recently. Do this experiment later.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>LAB. REPORT #1</u></b>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> 
</span>Using the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>netstat</b> output,
answer the following questions: </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l6 level1 lfo27;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>How would you calculate the average collision rate on
the network?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l6 level1 lfo27;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>What is the maximum transmission unit (MTU) of the
Ethernet interface on your system?</p>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.8<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Address Resolution Protocol (ARP)<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span> TC "2.4	Address Resolution
Protocol" \f C \l "2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Using
the IP address, a packet can be delivered up to the netwok that the destination
host resides. When the packet enters the destination network, it must follow
the physical layer protocols used by that network. The physical network does
not recognize IP addressing. Different kinds of physical networks have
different kinds of addressing schemes.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To
overcome this situation and run TCP/IP over many different kinds of physical
transmission media, the link layer provides the function that maps an IP
address to the physical network address. The protocol that performs the
translation of logical network address, i.e., the IP address, to the physical
hardware address is the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP).</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>The
ARP maintains the translation table which is built automatically. Once the ARP
creates an entry in the table, the entry has an expiration time of about 20
minutes. Even though the ARP table does not need any attention, with superuser
privilege, we can create and eliminate the ARP table entries. In the following
experiment, we shall see the contents of the ARP table and the operation of
ARP.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 2</u></b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>       </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Use</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>arp -v</b> </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>to see the entire ARP table
(Note: If ARP comes back with nothing, that means there are no entries in its
table, all have expired and been cleared.). Observe that all the IP addresses
displayed are on the same net/submet. While</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump -enx</b> <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>host</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>your_machine</i> </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>is running to capture traffic
between <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>your_machine</i> and the <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>other_machine</i>, that has currently <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>no entry</b> in the ARP table, execute <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>telnet</b> to the <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>other_machine</i> to generate traffic between them. If all the hosts
are in the ARP table, you need to delete a <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>host</i>
from the table using </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>arp -d</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>host</i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>That <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>host</i> then becomes the <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>other_machine</i> above! Note that only the
hardware address is removed from the table not the entire host entry.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Observe
the first few lines of the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump</b>
output to see how ARP operates. Examine the ARP translation table to see a new
line added. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>Save the <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>arp -v</b> command outputs before and after
you <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>telnet</b> to the another machine. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>Save the <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump </b>output of the first few packets
(ARP request/response) for the lab report. Note that if you only run one <b>tcpdump</b>
session on one machine, then you will only see the ARP request or the reply. If
you run tcpdump on both machines (i.e<b>. tcpdump –enx</b> <b>host</b> <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>your_machine</i> on your_machine and <b>tcpdump
–enx</b> <b>host</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>other_machine </i>on
the other_machine), then you will see both ARP reply and request in each <b>tcpdump</b>
output. Or if you run just <b>tcpdump –enx</b> you will capture all packets and
see both ARP messages.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>After getting
the necessary output, you may exit from the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>telnet</b> session.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>LAB. REPORT #2</u></b>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l7 level1 lfo28;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>From the saved<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>
tcpdump</b> output, explain how ARP operates. Identify and explain every field
in the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump</b> output related to
ARP.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l7 level1 lfo28;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Your report should include the answers to the following
questions:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.25in;
mso-list:l8 level1 lfo29;tab-stops:list .5in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>What is the target IP address in the ARP request?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.25in;
mso-list:l8 level1 lfo29;tab-stops:list .5in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>At the MAC layer, what is the destination Ethernet
address of the ARP request packet?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.25in;
mso-list:l8 level1 lfo29;tab-stops:list .5in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Who sends the ARP response packet? What Ethernet
addresses are used?</p>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.9<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>ICMP<!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span>
TC "2.5	ICMP" \f C \l "2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>For this section we will force an
error to occur to see the operation of ICMP. As an example we will execute a
simple file transfer using <b>tftp</b>. <b>tftp</b> uses UDP instead of TCP and
so when errors occur, ICMP kicks in to inform the application of any problems.
When executing <b>tftp</b>, it connects to its well known port on the
destination machine. By giving it a port number you are forcing it to use the
designated port number. If the number is invalid an error will occur.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 3</u></b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>       </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>While running <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump -x host</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>your_machine</i> <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>and</b> <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>other_machine</i>, type: </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tftp</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>After
getting the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tftp></b> prompt, type: </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>connect </b><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>other_machine</i><span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>8888 <o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>get </b><i><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>/root/.cshrc</span></i><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span></b>The wrong port is given
by the number <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>8888. </b>Quit the <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tftp</b> program and save the <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump</b> output.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>LAB. REPORT #3</u></b>: </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l10 level1 lfo30;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>In the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump</b>
file you will notice an ICMP port unreachable error. Explain the error message

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.11<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>    
</span><![endif]>Configuring Interfaces<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span> TC "2.7	Configuring
Interface" \f C \l "2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span></b>To change the IP
address of a PC, the<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'> ifconfig </b>command
can be used. The<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'> ifconfig</b> command is
used to set the interface address, the subnet mask, and the broadcast address.
Among the various functions we list the following which are sufficient for the
reconfiguration of the IP address and network mask.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>ifconfig -a</b> :<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>shows
the states of all interfaces in the system.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<h3><![if !supportLists]>1.11.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>   
</span><![endif]>Subnets<!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span>
TC "2.2	Subnet" \f C \l "2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 5</u></b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>       </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>With the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>ifconfig -a</b> command, find the IP address and the net mask of<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>your_machine</i>.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>LAB. REPORT #4</u></b>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> 
</span>Answer the following questions:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo26;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Based on the output of <b>ifconfig</b>, is the lab
network subnetted? How can you tell?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>What are the reasons for
subnetting?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<h3><![if !supportLists]>1.11.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>   
</span><![endif]>Configuring an Interface</h3>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>You first need to <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>deactivate</b> the network interface before
you can do anything to it. Type:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ifconfig eth0 down<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoFooter style='tab-stops:.5in'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>In
this section we will observe what happens when the same IP address is assigned
to two different hosts. We will also set an incorrect subnet mask for a host
and see what happens.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 6</u></b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Change
the IP address of one of the PCs (Orange in the table below) as follows:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<div align=center>

<table border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style='border-collapse:collapse;
 border:none;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .75pt;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
 <tr style='height:59.1pt'>
  <td width=264 valign=top style='width:2.75in;border:solid windowtext .75pt;
  padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;height:59.1pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>130.91.66.100<span
  style="mso-spacerun: yes">   </span>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  
  </span>apple.uci.edu</p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>130.91.66.100<span
  style="mso-spacerun: yes">   </span>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  
  </span>orange.uci.edu</p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>130.91.66.102<span
  style="mso-spacerun: yes">   </span>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  
  </span>peach.uci.edu</p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>130.91.66.103<span
  style="mso-spacerun: yes">   </span>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  
  </span>plum.uci.edu</p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyTextIndent>First deactivate the network interface of Orange by
logging onto Orange and typing: <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ifconfig
eth0 down</b>. Then to assign a new <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>IP
address</i> to a PC interface<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>(e.g.
assigning IP address 130.91.66.100 to Orange) type:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ifconfig eth0</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>IP address<o:p></o:p></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></i></p>

<p class=MsoBodyTextIndent><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Activate</b>
the network interface by typing:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ifconfig eth0 up<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyTextIndent>Then delete the ARP table entries of all the <u><span
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>other</span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'> </b></u>PCs using <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>arp –d </b><i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>host </i>on each PC (<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>Note</b>: do not delete the entry of the <u>host itself</u> or that of
the <u>multicast address</u> 224.0.0.0).</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Run
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump</b> on any PC to observe traffic
related to one of the PCs with a unique address, e.g., Peach (IP address:
130.91.66.102) or Plum (IP address 130.91.66.103):</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><span
style="mso-spacerun: yes"> </span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump
-e host 130.91.66.102<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'>or</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump -e host 130.91.66.103</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>First,
execute <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>telnet</b> from one of the two
PCs with the duplicate IP address to a PC with a unique IP address (e.g., <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>apple --> peach</b>) for which you are
running <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump</b>.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Now,
from the other PC with the duplicate IP address, execute the <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>telnet</b> command to the same PC (<b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>orange --> peach</b>).</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Observe
what happens and save the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump</b>
output and the ARP tables in all the PCs.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Second,
execute <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>telnet 130.91.66.100</b> from
peach.<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>      </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>LAB. REPORT #5</u></b>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> 
</span>Answer the following questions:</p>

style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To
set/change a subnet mask (e.g. <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>netmask</i>
= 255.255.255.240) type:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ifconfig eth0 down<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ifconfig eth0 netmask</b> <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>netmask<o:p></o:p></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ifconfig eth0 up</b><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'><o:p></o:p></i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyTextIndent2>In the table above, two hosts (apple and plum) have
been assigned the incorrect subnet masks. Use the ifconfig command to change
the subnet masks on these two hosts.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Capture
the packets with the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tcpdump -e</b>
command for the following scenarios:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>1.
when <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>130.91.66.100 </b>sends a <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ping</b> message to one of the hosts that
has the correct subnet mask.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>2.
when <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>130.91.66.120</b> sends a <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ping</b> message to one of the hosts that
has the correct subnet mask.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>3.
when a host with the correct subnet mask sends a <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>ping</b> message to <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>130.91.66.100</b>.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>4.
when a host with the correct subnet mask sends the <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>ping</b> message to <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>130.91.66.120</b>.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To
avoid confusion, only one machine should generate traffic in each case.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Explain what happened in each case from the <b

PCs with the new subnet mask cannot be reached from the other PCs; whilst the

output to illustrate your explanation and include the examples in your lab
report.</p>
